texts.shortText:
Abundant, large and conspicuous species often occurring in large, close-packed colonies that completely coat sand-filled gullies, or cover flat rocks subject to sand inundation. Occurs in a wide range of colours, including browns, pinks, reds and blues. Column wide and bearing numerous sticky knobs to which sand grains and pieces of shell strongly adhere. Closes up tightly when exposed at low tide, concealing the tentacles so that the colonies resemble sheets of small sandy hummocks. Tentacles short and closely packed, up to 384 in number, often with opaque white spots.

Juveniles often attached to mussels.
Column diameter typically up to 80 mm, tentacles only about 10 mm long.

Global: Endemic to Namibia and South Africa.

Local/Regional: Southern Namibia to St Lucia in northern KwaZulu-Natal, but most abundant along west coast.

A very common, large and well-known species that can be extremely abundant on the west coast, where it carpets sandy gullies and low-lying rocks. Colonies include adjacent individuals of a wide range of bright colours, forming an attractive mosaic when open.

A classic wait-and-see predator that occupies low-lying rocks beneath densely colonized reefs and feeds almost entirely on tumbled prey dislodged from adjacent rocks or swept in by the waves. The diet is diverse with the most frequently consumed items being barnacles, mussels, gastropods and polychaete worms. Almost any organic item will be eaten though and it is quite common to see individuals trying to consume large urchins, rock-lobster or crab moults, discarded fishing bait, etc.

Anemones can reproduce sexually, by releasing sperm and eggs into the water, and this species can be seen undertaking mass spawning events in which sperm and eggs are pouring from the apertures of each colony member. They can also divide by fission, so where similarly-coloured individuals are found in close proximity these are probably derived by division of a single founding individual.

Sometimes confused with the knobbly anemone Bunodosoma capense, which not only has a similar generic name, but also occurs in a wide range of colours and is found on the same shores. However, the knobs on the column of the knobbly anemone are not sticky and sand grains do not adhere to them. That species also tends to occur singly or in small groups in clean sand-free sites.
